Question_1.Context: The study investigated the effects of cow milk-derived fat on human hepatoma HepG2 cells.
Question_1.Question: What is the most abundant saturated fatty acid found in cow milk-derived fat?
Question_1.Source: Although season, breed, climate, health, diet, and lactation stage can affect the fatty acid composition of cow milk, palmitic acid (16:0) is the most abundant saturated fatty acid.

Question_2.Context: The study explored the potential anticancer properties of cow milk-derived fat on liver cancer cells.
Question_2.Question: Which fatty acid has been shown to exert anticancer effects on non-small cell lung carcinoma cells?
Question_2.Source: Heptadecanoic acid (C17:0) exerts anticancer effects on non-small cell lung carcinoma cells.

Question_3.Context: The study focused on the effects of cow milk-derived fat on cell cycle progression in HepG2 cells.
Question_3.Question: What is the most abundant monounsaturated fatty acid found in cow milk-derived fat?
Question_3.Source: Among monounsaturated fatty acids, oleic acid (C18:1) is the most abundant in cow milk-derived fat.

Question_4.Context: The study examined the histone deacetylase inhibitory potential of cow milk-derived fat.
Question_4.Question: Which fatty acid has been identified as a novel inhibitor of histone deacetylase 6?
Question_4.Source: A recent study identified a series of odd-chain fatty acids as novel inhibitors of histone deacetylase (HDAC) 6.

Question_5.Context: The study investigated the antioxidant effects of cow milk-derived fat.
Question_5.Question: What method was used to assess the DPPH radical scavenging ability of cow milk-derived fat?
Question_5.Source: The results of the DPPH assay in this study indicated that cow milk-derived fat can scavenge DPPH free radicals in a dose-dependent manner.

Question_6.Context: The study focused on the effects of cow milk-derived fat on liver cancer cells.
Question_6.Question: Which signaling pathway was assessed in HepG2 cells when exposed to cow milk-derived fat?
Question_6.Source: We observed a significant decrease in the level of pSTAT-3/STAT-3 and, although not statistically significant, a decrease in the level of pJAK-2/JAK-2 in HepG2 cells when exposed to cow milk-derived fat.

Question_7.Context: The study examined the effects of cow milk-derived fat on cell viability in HepG2 cells.
Question_7.Question: What was the IC50 value for cow milk-derived fat after 48 hours of exposure?
Question_7.Source: Following exposure to cow-milk fat, dose- and time-dependent inhibition of cell viability was observed with IC50 values 1.501 ± 0.053 mg/mL and 1.299 ± 0.046 mg/mL for 24 and 48 h, respectively.

Question_8.Context: The study investigated the effects of cow milk-derived fat on colony formation in HepG2 cells.
Question_8.Question: What was the main finding regarding the colony formation ability of HepG2 cells exposed to cow milk-derived fat?
Question_8.Source: The colony formation assay revealed that cow milk significantly inhibited colony formation in HepG2 cells.

Question_9.Context: The study explored the apoptotic potential of cow milk-derived fat in HepG2 cells.
Question_9.Question: What was observed in HepG2 cells exposed to cow milk-derived fat regarding chromatin condensation?
Question_9.Source: Hoechst 33,342 staining was employed to determine whether cow milk-derived fat mediates cytotoxic effects by inducing apoptosis. Chromatin condensation, a biochemical characteristic of apoptosis, was observed in HepG2 cells exposed to cow-milk fat.

Question_10.Context: The study focused on the effects of cow milk-derived fat on HDAC activity.
Question_10.Question: What was the main finding regarding the HDAC inhibitory potential of cow milk-derived fat?
Question_10.Source: As shown in Fig. 4, cow milk-derived fat inhibited HDAC activity in a dose-dependent manner, highlighting the HDAC-inhibitory potential of cow milk-derived fat.
